description:
A: Hey Trevor.
B: Oh, hey Cheryl. How's your day going?
A: So far, so good. Just prepping for a class. You?
B: Same. Did you get some lunch?
A: Yeah. I had a burrito. You?
B: Tuna sandwich.
A: Actually, there's something I want to ask you.
B: Yeah? What about?
A: Did you just ask me about what I had for lunch because you were actually curious?
B: Of course. Why else would I ask?
A: Oh, OK. No I... It's just that, I keep getting that same question over and over again. Like, almost everyone I run into. I know they're just making small talk, but it's funny. Everyone seems so keen on finding out what I ate.
B: Well, I guess you could think of it as small talk. But for us, it's more or less how we greet each other. So, when we ask that, it's effectively saying like "How are you?".
A: Oh~ Is that right?
B: Not always, but most of the time. Yes.

ì‰¬ìš´ ë‹¨ì–´ë“¤ë¡œ ì¡°í•©í•œ ìì£¼ ì“°ëŠ” ì˜ì–´ í‘œí˜„ 5ê°œ.

1. to pick up where one left off
- Let's pick up where we left off.
- We could do this all night. Let's call it a day. We'll pick up where we left off tomorrow.

2. to put something on hold
- Let's put this on hold.
- I had to put all my personal plans on hold.

3. to drop something / everything to attend to more pressing matters
- Listen up everybody. Dr. Kramer is arriving in less than an hour. You know how he is a messy office. Drop what you're doing now and tidy this place up.
- How could you say that? I've always been there for you. Anytime you needed me, I dropped everything to help you.

4. to open up (about something / to someone)
- You should definitely try therapy. I understand it can be difficult to open up to someone you don't know. But once you get past that, it's so worth it.
- Did you read her book? There was a lot I didn't know about her. I was especially surprised at how much she opened up about her experience with addiction.

5. get through to someone (to get someone to listen and comply)
- You're never going to get through to him like that.
- 15? That's a difficult age. I remember when my kids were that age. I didn't have much trouble with my daughter, but no matter what I did, I just couldn't get through to my son. It was like we spoke different languages.

title: Paris Hilton reveals her show with Nicole Richie starts filming THIS WEEK
description:
In an interview with Fortune, Paris Hilton revealed that her new show with Nicole Richie begins filming this Friday, June 28. The entrepreneur and musician was promoting the new Motorola Razr flip phone at an event in New York City. Both the Razr and Hilton's iconic show The Simple Life came out 20 years ago, and both are coming back into the zeitgeist as Gen Z embraces nostalgia for the early 2000s. As Hilton would say, "That's hot."

title: How Being the Only Woman in the Room Helped Me Start a $2 Billion Platform
description:
Ellevest's founder Sallie Krawcheck climbed the glass cliffs at Wall Street only to see a growing issue once she reached the top. The wealth inequality between men and women was staggering, and women's wealth was even going backwards compared to men's. Knowing that the investing industry tends to mostly serve men, Krawcheck took it into her own hands to build a $2 billion empire dedicated to helping women build their own wealth.

title: Boeing CEO Admits His $32.8 Million Salary Is 'A Big Number'
description:
â€œIâ€™m sticking this through. Iâ€™m proud of having taken the job.â€

Boeing CEO David Calhoun defended the companyâ€™s safety record during a contentious Senate hearing last week, while lawmakers accused him of placing profits over safety, failing to protect whistleblowers, and even getting paid too much.

Relatives of people who died in two crashes of Boeing 737 Max jetliners were in the room, some holding photos of their loved ones, to remind the CEO of the stakes. Calhoun began his remarks by standing, turning to face the families, and apologizing â€œfor the grief that we have caused,â€ and vowing to focus on safety.

â€œI am proud of every action we have taken,â€ Calhoun said.

Read more: https://fortune.com/2024/06/19/boeing-ceo-david-calhoun-strip-mining-company-profit-senators-safety-scandals-planemaker/

title: Shake Shack Leaders Discuss Papa Johns CEO Takeover, the Fast Food Debate and New Israel Branch
description:
On the latest episode of Executive Exchange, Leadership Editor Ruth Umoh sits down with legendary Shake Shack founder Danny Meyer and former CEO Randy Garutti to discuss the latter's departure, what he accomplished at the burger empire for over 2 decades, and what lies ahead for the brand.

What started out as a hotdog cart in Madison Square Park in 2001, has now transformed into a $4 billion global behemoth. Former CEO Randy Garutti talks about working alongside Danny for 24 years in the restaurant industry and the impact he's had on his career throughout their time together. Randy leaves the company that now has over 540 restaurants in 19 countries.

Danny reminisces about meeting Randy for the first time at his very first restaurant, Tabla, when he hired him to become manager of the restaurant. But once Shake Shack started to hit its stride in Madison Square Park, Randy was ready to step up to the plate and lead the team.

They also discuss the new CEO, Rob Lynch, stepping in from Papa Johns to lead the team and if there's ever going to be pizza on the Shake Shack menu. Their vision for Lynch is to mold new leaders in the brand to step up into larger roles in the future, just as they had done previously with Randy at the helm.

Finally, the two discuss the latest conflicts in the Israel-Hamas conflict and the boycott that happened at the company as well as what their favorite orders are at Shake Shack. Danny is a little surprised at Randy's go to order.

description:

But the company was formed in an unexpected place. 31 years ago, Jensen Huang, Chris Malachowsky, and Curtis Priem met at a Dennyâ€™s restaurant, where Huang had once worked as a dishwasher and busboy.

When Nvidia started in 1993, Huang, along with co-founders Chris Malachowsky and Curtis Priem, began with an idea of creating chips that would enable realistic 3D graphics on personal computersâ€”or graphic processing units, specifically for video games.

title: How Milk Bar Went From Baking in the Basement to Making Taylor Swiftâ€™s Birthday Cake
description:
Christina Tosi, the chef and founder of â€œmodern Americanâ€ bakery Milk Bar, has never shied away from a challenge. 

Tosi, 42, has loved all things sugar and baking since she was a kid in Ohio. Her summer job after freshman year of college brought her to a tiny island off the coast of New Hampshire, churning out baked goods in an industrial kitchen with no professional experience. That was her a-ha moment that drew her away from a career in math and into the baking world for good.

But it was working as a pastry chef at Bouley, a sceney restaurant in downtown New York City,  that introduced her to the actual work of professional baking. After meeting and working under David Chang of Momofuku fame, Tosi honed her craft, made countless experiments, and with his support, spun her dessert menu into a standalone business: Milk Bar. And she did it without a graphic designer; that curly neon pink logo you may be familiar with? She made it herself on Microsoft Word.

In an interview with Fortune, Tosi revealed her secrets to success and walked through all of Milk Barâ€™s biggest failuresâ€”and why she â€œdrinks them up for breakfast.â€

Today's video features John Whaley, the founder of Inception Studio. Inception Studio is a non-profit accelerator for experienced founders at the earliest stage who aim to start companies built around AI from the ground up. Prior to founding Inception Studio, Whaley built two other companies. In this video, you'll learn about the major lessons he gained from his challenging career journey, and he also shares his outlook on the future of AI companies.

title: Age 27, Built a $230M AI Lawyer Business | Joshua Browder, DoNotPay
description:
Meet Joshua Browder, CEO of DoNotPay, a company dedicated to saving people money by assisting with tasks like contesting parking tickets. Browder, who started the venture at 17 while a student at Stanford University, was inspired by his own experience receiving 30 parking tickets after moving from England to Silicon Valley. He discusses transforming personal problems into startup ideas, securing initial investment from Silicon Valley, and shares insights on the future of AI.

title: Advice from an investor managing a $30B Fundã…£AIM Congress, Dawood Al Shezawi
description:
Dawood Al Shezawi is the President of AIM Global Foundation and AIM Congress, a platform dedicated to fostering global economic relations and addressing investment challenges. In this role, he plays a key part in facilitating communication among global leaders and stakeholders in the investment field. Al Shezawi is instrumental in promoting collaboration, emphasizing the potential for growth, and discussing solutions for a sustainable future.

title: How Our Company Is Growing 4X ANNUALLY | Krepling Liam J.E Gerada
description:
EO Builders Club | A Membership Community for certified founders & global entrepreneurs, connected through EO's powerful resources
Enter Now ğŸ‘‰ https://bit.ly/3TQfmYW

We interviewed Liam Gerada about his career journey and insights. Liam is the co-founder and CEO of Krepling. We uncover his remarkable journey from teenage entrepreneur to leading a cutting-edge e-commerce platform. Krepling's AI-driven solution empowers brands to thrive in the digital marketplace without coding, a vision born from Liam's experience founding The Kingsfare at just 17. Discover how Liam's entrepreneurial spirit and innovative mindset are reshaping e-commerce, offering accessible solutions for businesses to succeed online. Don't miss this inspiring conversation!

description:
Discover how ONE.orgâ€™s new Data Commons is transforming decision-making and solving real-world problems in the fight against poverty. This innovative tool, an open source initiative by Google, seamlessly integrates ONE's data with global datasets, unlocking valuable insights through natural language queries. By building their own Data Commons, ONE.org has simplified their data processes, leveraging billions of data points from around the world and empowering their team to explore, analyze, and share data-driven insights effortlessly. This powerful resource seamlessly integrates public and private data for comprehensive analysis and visualization, maintaining full control over data and resources, including managing access. #OneCampaign #DataCommons #Google

title: A Question to Ask Ourselves When We Are Low and Paranoid
description:
Thereâ€™s a difficult mood weâ€™re in danger of falling into thatâ€™s made up of four elements in particular: low spirits, guilt, paranoia and irritability. Itâ€™s in such a mood that we might step back and ask ourselves a distinctive question:

 "Might I - at heart - be very angry with someone right now?"

â€œThereâ€™s a difficult mood weâ€™re in danger of falling into thatâ€™s made up of four elements in particular: low spirits, guilt, paranoia and irritability. In such a mood, we may feel guilty and ashamed without being able to put a finger on anything concrete weâ€™ve done. At the same time, weâ€™re in a paranoid state of mind, as if people out there didnâ€™t like us especially, or we were in imminent danger of being found out for doing something forbidden. And then we might feel non-specifically irritable â€“ and get uncommonly grumpy when we canâ€™t find a household item or the printer jamsâ€¦â€

â€œMissing someone that weâ€™re close to â€“ because theyâ€™ve had to go to another country, or are up in the north on a course, or went on a hiking trip with their friends â€“ is such an unpleasant emotion, it feels peculiar to suggest that it is also, at a profound level, an extraordinary achievement and an important marker of emotional maturity. It is in no way simple for a prototypical adult to be able to miss anyone and we are often, almost without knowing it, engaged in complex manoeuvres to ensure that we resolutely wonâ€™tâ€¦â€

description:
Enjoying our Youtube videos? Get full access to all our audio content, videos, and thousands of thought-provoking articles, conversation cards and more with The School of Life Subscription: https://t.ly/NIG9F

You can read more on this and other subjects in our articles, here: https://t.ly/vWIPK

â€œWe hear so much about the difficulties caused by those who cannot be intimate, who seem incapable of disclosing anything of what they genuinely feel, it can take time to register the opposite but no less grave problem: those who cannot keep enough of themselves to themselves, those whose hunger for closeness overwhelms their concern for their own safety, those who will, in a poignant bid to hold othersâ€™ attention, lay out â€“ within minutes of a new encounter â€“ secrets that they would have been wiser to take to the grave.
This isnâ€™t to deny the fun that oversharers can bring to social life. These wonâ€™t be the types talking about the economic contraction or where they last went on holiday. Contact with other humans should be about getting to the marrow of things, they believe, which is why we will quickly get to hear about their exâ€™s sexual difficulty, the vicious row they had about their motherâ€™s will, exactly how much they earn, the troubles they have with their digestion, their favourite bedroom position and the nature of an early childhood traumaâ€¦

title: When and Why do we Pick Up our Phones?
description:
We may check our phones to see if any messages might have come in, if someone posted an interesting film, if something dreadful has happened overseas. But this is in danger of sounding far too normal and too kind to us. The truth is a lot darker and rather more humbling.

Enjoying our Youtube videos? Get full access to all our audio content, videos, and thousands of thought-provoking articles, conversation cards and more with The School of Life Subscription: https://t.ly/8lEEx

Learn, heal and grow. Get the best of The School of Life delivered straight to your inbox: https://t.ly/P3C2N

FURTHER READING

You can read more on this and other subjects in our articles, here: https://t.ly/Ln8RA

â€œThere are the standard, conventional-sounding answers: we check our phones to see if any messages might have come in, if someone posted an interesting film, if something dreadful has happened overseas.
But this is in danger of sounding far too normal and too kind to us. The truth is a lot darker and rather more humbling. We donâ€™t pick up our phones to find out whatâ€™s going on, we pick them up to ensure â€“ with considerable ruthlessness â€“ that we are in no danger of finding out anything more about ourselves.
If we forensically study the moments when we are drawn to pick up our devices, these are almost always when some kind of anxiety is pressing in on us â€“ an anxiety on whose analysis and interpretation the correct navigation of our lives may depend. We are using our devices as an alternative to thinking about our futures, we employ our machines to block insight, to halt the business of processing, to alienate our minds from their most promising and complex substrataâ€¦â€

title: How to Find Out What's Really on Your Mind
description:
Enjoying our Youtube videos? Get full access to all our audio content, videos, and thousands of thought-provoking articles, conversation cards and more with The School of Life Subscription: https://t.ly/1l2hk

Learn, heal and grow. Get the best of The School of Life delivered straight to your inbox: https://t.ly/8YVAl

You can read more on this and other subjects in our articles, here: https://t.ly/1gfLW

â€œThis is a psychological game that offers us an entertaining and unique way to learn about whatâ€™s really going on in our minds. Weâ€™re offered the beginnings of a story â€“ and are then invited to imagine the rest. What might happen to the little boy and girl lost in the forest, or the old wizard who has just come across an ancient book in a monastery or the shipwrecked sailor on a dark volcanic island? The way we complete the story ends up showing us a remarkable, immense amount about our values, fears, concerns and hopes. Play the game in company for entertainment and confession; play it on your own to mine the contents of your deep selfâ€¦â€

title: How To Overcome Psychological Barriers
description:
We humans are extraordinarily and painfully vulnerable creatures. Especially in our early years, we are at huge danger of being psychologically damaged by those around us. Damage is in one way or another always caused by a shortfall of tenderness and care. As we might put it, itâ€™s caused by a shortfall of love. Examples of shortfalls of love are very varied: perhaps at an early point someone went missing or someone died, someone was cruel or someone misunderstood.  And as a result of this deficit, universally, some kind of wound was sustainedâ€¦


Enjoying our Youtube videos? Get full access to all our audio content, videos, and thousands of thought-provoking articles, conversation cards and more with The School of Life Subscription: https://t.ly/kBCyt


Learn, heal and grow. Get the best of The School of Life delivered straight to your inbox: https://t.ly/C4a6_

FURTHER READING

You can read more on this and other subjects in our articles, here: https://t.ly/AP-H-

â€œ1. We humans are extraordinarily and painfully vulnerable creatures. Especially in our early years, we are at huge danger of being psychologically damaged by those around us. Damage is in one way or another always caused by a shortfall of tenderness and care. As we might put it, itâ€™s caused by a shortfall of love.
Examples of shortfalls of love are very varied: perhaps at an early point someone went missing or someone died, someone was cruel or someone misunderstood. 
And as a result of this deficit, universally, some kind of wound was sustained.

2. We are psychologically very ingenious creatures. In the face of any wound, we develop an array of very clever defence mechanisms. The purpose of defence mechanisms is to protect us against further damage, to help us to get through to the next stage of existence; to keep us going; in extremes, to save our livesâ€¦â€

title: Two Questions to Repair a Relationship  #animation #shorts  #relationships
description:
How can we prevent damage in our relationships? To start with we can regularly ask our partners two ostensibly simple yet hugely central and effective questionsâ€¦

Enjoying our Youtube videos? Get full access to all our audio content, videos, and thousands of thought-provoking articles, conversation cards and more with The School of Life Subscription: https://t.ly/843mW

Be more mindful, present and inspired. Get the best of The School of Life delivered straight to your inbox: https://t.ly/GMpyM

You can read more on this here: https://9qq0.short.gy/ys7oSs

â€œRelationships get damaged; every day brings with it small challenges - disappointments, frustrations, and irritations - that can come between even the most committed lovers and subtly wear away at the sincerity of their connection. 

To prevent the risks, lovers should regularly make room to ask themselves - in a calm spirit of gentle openness and curiosity - two ostensibly simple yet hugely central and effective questions:

What are you angry with me about?

How have I scared you recently?â€

â€œMissing someone that weâ€™re close to â€“ because theyâ€™ve had to go to another country, or are up in the north on a course, or went on a hiking trip with their friends â€“ is such an unpleasant emotion, it feels peculiar to suggest that it is also, at a profound level, an extraordinary achievement and an important marker of emotional maturity. It is in no way simple for a prototypical adult to be able to miss anyone and we are often, almost without knowing it, engaged in complex manoeuvres to ensure that we resolutely wonâ€™tâ€¦â€

title: How to Overcome Trauma  #shorts  #trauma  #understandingtheself
description:
Full Film: https://youtu.be/CHm2gTkNQxc

A great many of us have - in one way or another - been traumatised somewhere in our past. Not only have we suffered greatly, we are likely not to have been able properly to process and digest what we have gone through. A key feature of a good life is a capacity to look our trauma in the eye; and ensure that the future can be a whole lot more hopeful than the past.

â€œPsychological trauma can be defined as a negative event so overwhelming that we cannot properly understand, process or move on from it â€“ but, and this is the devilish aspect to it, nor can we properly remember it or reflect upon its nature and its effects on us. It is lodged within us but remains hidden from us, making its presence known only via symptoms and pains, altering our sense of reality without alerting us to its devilish subterranean operations.â€

Whereas we on the other hand â€“ as all our acquaintances know â€“ are the emotionally fluent ones. We long to be close to someone, we long to discuss our feelings openly and without restraint, we are healthy and ready for love. title: The One Question You Need to Understand Who You Are
description:
There is one question that, perhaps more than any other, gets to the root of who we are and what motivates us: â€œWhat did I need to do in childhood to win the support and approval of my parents?â€ We might - to sharpen the picture - need to lean on a few subsidiary enquiriesâ€¦

You can read more on this and other subjects in our articles, here: https://t.ly/JYcLU

â€œThere is one question that, perhaps more than any other, gets to the root of who we are and what motivates us:
                    
          What did I need to do in childhood to win the support and approval of my parents?

We might - to sharpen the picture - need to lean on a few subsidiary enquiries:

To please my father, I needed toâ€¦
To please my mother, I needed toâ€¦

Not to upset my mother, I needed toâ€¦
Not to upset my father, I needed toâ€¦

Whatever might be claimed, no family ever gives its offspring unconditional love; there is always, more or less subtly, something that one has to do and to be - and other things that must at all costs be skirtedâ€¦â€

Life sometimes leads us down paths we didn't choose. 
These paths can often be unfamiliar and challenging, requiring us to let go of things we hold dear. 
But when we muster the courage to choose these paths, we often discover unexpected gifts.

For me, that gift was my spouse. 
Over the past 7 years, they have been my excitement and my driving force, but also, at times, my loneliness. 
However, if I could go back to that day 7 years ago, I would choose to embark on that journey to England to find them once again.

Even when you feel lost, don't be afraid. 
Because at the end of those paths, there may be beautiful treasures waiting for us, ones we couldn't have imagined. 

Today, we promise each other eternal love. 
Just like we have until now, we'll continue to stumble and lose our way, but now, we won't be alone; we'll have each other.

To everyone who has joined us today, I sincerely thank you. We hope that our story will inspire and comfort you as well.


From ì°¨ë‹ˆ Chan

It was around christmas time in 2016 when I first met Minjung, 
that turned out to be the best present and she would become the most important part of my future.

Since then we have been on countless adventures, visited many beautiful countries and shared way too much yummy food.
Our love has grown day on day and year on year and I count myself incredibly lucky every day I get to see her smile

We are going to embark on the next chapter of our lives soon, 
settling down together after far too many years of long distance, 
I can finally face each new day with my soulmate by my side.

Everyday we have spoken since we became a couple I have told Minjung I love her,
I will continue to tell her until my last breath.
I will shower her with my love and affection every single day and ensure she is safe and happy always.

title: A Week in My Life Vlog | Joshua Tree Girls Trip & Office Tour
description:
A Week in My Life Vlog | Go toÂ https://drinkag1.com/sannevloetyt to get a FREE 1-year supply of Vitamin D3+K2 and 5 AG1 travelÂ packs with your first purchase. Thanks to AG1 for sponsoring today's video!

Hi,

Welcome to a new video! It finally starts to feel like summer here on the west coast and I am happy that June gloom is finally fading out. It's been so grounding and fun to be home and just to do fun activities out and about. My friend Sylvie (@kettlepaints) came to visit us from Australia and we decided to go out to Joshua Tree. She will be staying in our place for the upcoming month while she is working on some new paintings. 

I wanted to take you with and share snippets of my daily life. Hope you enjoy!

X Sanne

Spinach Salad with Grilled Salmon, Purple Sweet Potatoes, Edamame, Green Onions, and Avocado with Miso Dressing Recipe ( 2 servings)

Ingredients:

â€¢ For the Salmon Marinade:
o 2 salmon fillets
o 3 tablespoons soy sauce
o 2 tablespoons honey
o 1 tablespoon olive oil
o 1 clove garlic, minced
o 1 teaspoon ginger, grated
o Juice of 1 lime

â€¢ For the Purple Sweet Potatoes:
o 2 medium purple sweet potatoes


â€¢ For the Salad:
o 4 cups fresh spinach leaves
o 1 cup shelled edamame (cooked and cooled)
o 2 green onions, thinly sliced
o 1 avocado, sliced
o 1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro (optional)
o Sesame seeds for garnish (optional)

â€¢ For the Miso Dressing:
o 2 tablespoons white miso paste
o 2 tablespoons rice vinegar
o 1 tablespoon soy sauce
o 1 tablespoon sesame oil
o 1 tablespoon honey or maple syrup
o 1 teaspoon grated ginger
o 2 tablespoons water (to thin the dressing if needed)

Instructions:
1. Marinate the Salmon:
1. In a small bowl, whisk together the soy sauce, honey, olive oil, minced garlic, grated ginger, and lime juice.
2. Place the salmon fillets in a shallow dish and pour the marinade over them. Let them marinate in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes.
2. Bake the Purple Sweet Potatoes:
1. Preheat your oven to 400Â°F (200Â°C).
2. Wash and scrub the sweet potatoes, then pat them dry.
3. Wrap the sweet potatoes with aluminium foil and and bake for about 50 minutes, or until tender.* ( I love to meal prep these and have in my fridge)
4. Allow the sweet potatoes to cool, then peel and cut them into bite-sized pieces.
3. Grill the Salmon: Put the salmon for 8 minutes on 380F in airfryer 
4. Prepare the Salad:
1. In a large bowl, combine the spinach leaves, cooked edamame, sliced green onions, and cilantro if using.
2. Add the cooled sweet potato pieces and avocado slices.
5. Make the Miso Dressing:
1. In a small bowl, whisk together the white miso paste, rice vinegar, soy sauce, sesame oil, honey or maple syrup, and grated ginger.
2. Add water gradually to thin the dressing to your desired consistency.
6. Assemble the Salad:
1. Drizzle the miso dressing over the salad and toss gently to combine.
2. Top with the grilled salmon fillets, breaking them into large chunks if desired.
3. Garnish with sesame seeds if using.
7. Serve:
o Serve immediately and enjoy your nutritious and delicious spinach salad with grilled salmon!
Tips:
â€¢ Prepare the sweet potatoes and edamame in advance to save time.

title: WHAT I EAT IN A WEEK | high protein to build lean muscle | easy home recipes
description:
WHAT I EAT IN A WEEK | high protein to build lean muscle & boost metabolism | Soul Sync Body High Protein Meal Plan - start your 7 day free trial here: https://www.soulsyncbody.com or join me with the E-book https://bit.ly/3R5Kcw5

Hi,

Thank you so much for waiting for this vlog! This is the first time I'm sharing such a long vlog, but I had too many good recipes to keep it short. This week, I'm sharing everything I ate on the new High Protein Meal Plan from Soul Sync Body, part of my 4-week Power Pilates Program.

Many of you reached out for high-protein recipes after I shared my nutrition journey over the past year. I've seen incredible results by integrating more protein into my diet, including building lean muscle, feeling stronger and more energized, and balancing my hormones. No matter your health and wellness goalsâ€”whether it's losing weight, becoming more toned, having more energy, building lean muscle, or boosting your metabolismâ€”protein is key!

I started designing this meal plan in February, so it's been a work in progress haha! The meal plan includes diverse recipes for two weeks, so if you enjoy this week, there's another whole week ready for you! While everyone's protein needs are different, this meal plan provides around 90-100g protein a day and is an excellent framework to get started. Our dietitian Dominika explains more about individual protein needs in the e-book but make sure to always check with your health care provider. 

I hope you love it as much as I do! If you want to support or follow along, you can become a Soul Sync Body member to access the Power Pilates workouts, guided meal plan, and all recipes. Or, if you want to focus solely on the nutrition program, you can download the e-book below!

After this meal plan my hope is that you feel increased energy, strength, and fullness after completing these four weeks and continue to upkeep new protein habits in your future!!

Much love,
Sanne

title: 4x Things I Did To Balance My Hormones
description:
4x Things I Did To Balance My Hormones | Let's get personal

Hi friend, 

Today, I want to get a bit personal with you all. One of the best decisions I've ever made was opening up about my hormonal health journey. Before sharing it openly on social media, I never realized how many of you were going through the same thing. Hormonal issues can manifest in various waysâ€”acne, skin problems, weight fluctuations, mood swings, irregular periods, you name it.

Over the years, I've experimented with many habits and learned a ton from experts in the field. I'm excited to share some tips and tricks that have truly transformed my life and journey.

One big aspect I've found crucial is nutrition. It plays a huge role in our hormone health. Inspired by this, I worked together with my friend and registered dietitian, Dominika, to create a full library of hormone-friendly recipes on Soul Sync Body. These are recipes I've been making on repeat and can't wait to share with you all. ***

I hope this video can be helpful to you. And remember, wherever you are in your journey, be patient!

Sending much love,

Sanne

Discover secret features, quick access to your calendar (especially when Notion docs are attached), custom database widgets and a sneak peek into whatâ€™s to come.

title: Notion Home ğŸ   #tutorial #notion #home
description: Where your most relevant work and knowledge come together. Easily jump back into docs and projects, view calendar events, see assigned tasks, and pin your favorite databases for easy access.

title: Advanced database filters
description: Notion databases let you store large amounts of data, and visualize your content across tables, calendars, boards, and more. With advanced filter capabilities, you can make your database views even more powerful.

title: Admins, members & guests
description: In Notion, you can customize permission levels so that your colleagues, collaborators & clients only have access to the pages and settings they need. This video shows you how.

title: Meet Randy
description:
Meet Randy, Notion's new Head of Design. To learn more about Randy, check out our blog post here: 
https://www.notion.so/blog/meet-randy

title: Creating a page
description: In Notion, every new page that you create is a blank canvas where you can add whatever content you like. This video shows you how to add a new page to your Notion workspace.

title: Think it. Make it.
description:
Turn ideas into action with Notionâ€™s AI-powered workspace.

Learn more at http://notion.com/product

title: OKRs for Product & Engineering
description:
Notion is a connected workspace, powered by AI, that enables Product & Engineering teams to efficiently manage OKRs by integrating them with daily workflows. It provides a single source of truth for teams working towards the same goals, together.

Get the template: https://www.notion.so/templates/okrs-for-epd

title: Building a Global Community by Ivan Zhao, Simon Last, and Akshay Kothari, Co-Founders of Notion
description: Full episode: https://youtu.be/ZMrjvxCIPpY

title: First Block: Interview with Ivan Zhao and Simon Last, Co-Founders of Notion
description:
For an audio-only podcast and transcripts please visit: https://ntn.so/3Kir6g

To learn more about how Notion is supporting startups, please visit: https://ntn.so/BeIEen

First Block, a Notion series - hosted by Notion's Co-Founder Akshay Kothari - where founders and executives from some of the worldâ€™s leading companies tell us what it was like to navigate the many firsts of their startup journey â€” and what they learned from that experience.

In this episode, Akshay sits down with Notion co-founders Ivan Zhao and Simon Last to talk about everything Notion â€” where we started, how we got where we are now, and where weâ€™re headed.

title: Summer Break 2024 Episode + Zhamak Dehghani
description:
Joe and Matt are going to take the summer off from the Monday Morning Data Chat. They'll chat about what's on their minds, summer plans, and more.

Plus, special guest Zhamak Dehghani discusses the current state of Data Mesh, and what she's up to at NextData.

title: Chris Tabb - Platform Gravity & Combining App, Data, and Algorithms
description: Chris Tabb joins us to chat about something on his mind - platform gravity. The direction seems be the unified platform that combines applications, data, and algorithms. Chris is here to shed light on this trend.

title: Ghalib Suleiman - The Zero-Interest Rate Hangover in Data and AI
description: Ghalib Suleiman (Polytomic) joins the show to chat how the zero-interest rate hangover is affecting data and AI. We dive into the AI hype cycle, "data influencers", data vendors, data teams, and much more.

title: Bart Vandekerckhove - Data Security Deep Dive
description: Bart Vandekerckhove (Raito) joins us to chat about data security, and the challenges data teams face when using traditional IAM technology and workflows for data access/security management.

title: Yali Sassoon - Using LLMs to Support the Analytics Workflow
description:
It seems like LLMs are taking the analytics world by storm. But how do you use them to support the analytics workflow? 

Yali Sassoon (CTO, Co-founder of Snowplow) joins us to chat about this and much more. We'll also likely dive into behavioral analytics and more.

Snowplow: https://snowplow.io/

title: David Yaffe & John Kutay - The State of Streaming and CDC
description:
David Yaffe (Estuary) and John Kutay (Striim) join the show to chat about the state of streaming and change data capture (CDC) in 2024 and beyond. There is a lot to cover and learn in this show.

Estuary: https://estuary.dev/
Striim: https://www.striim.com/

#dataengineering #data #ai

title: Solomon Kahn - Customer-Facing Data Products
description:
Data products are all the rage. But what are they? And what the heck does "customer-facing" mean? Will your old-school BI tool handle customer-facing needs?

Solomon Kahn joins us to chat about customer-facing data products and much more. He's one of the people we consider to be at the bleeding edge of modern analytics and data products, so definitely check this out.

Delivery Layer: https://www.deliverylayer.com/
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/solomonkahn/

title: Katharine Jarmul - Are We Solving the "Right" Problems with AI?
description:
Katharine Jarmul is a AI/ML privacy and security expert, and the author of Practical Data Privacy. She joins us to chat about whether we are solving the "right" problems with AI/ML/data science, exploring what "safe", "responsible", and "ethical" AI means, and much more.

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/katharinejarmul/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/kjam?lang=en
Probably Private (newsletter): https://probablyprivate.com/
Practical Data Privacy: https://learning.oreilly.com/library/view/practical-data-privacy/9781098129453/

title: Matt Turck - The 2024 MAD Landscape (Special Show)
description: Matt Turck joins us for a special chat about the newly released 2024 MAD (ML, AI, and Data) Landscape. There's a TON happening at light speed in the AI and data space right now, and Matt and the FirstMark crew have done a phenomenal job keeping a pulse on things.

title: Cedric Chin & Sam Taylor - Communicating Sophisticated Stuff to Stakeholders
description:
Cedric Chin (CommonCog) and Sam Taylor join us to chat about communicating sophisticated stuff to stakeholders, process control, XmR charts, and a ton more.

CommonCog: https://commoncog.com/
XmRit: https://xmrit.com/

title: Martin Musiol - Generative AI: Navigating the Course to the AGI Future
description: Martin Musiol (Founder and CEO of generativeAI.net and GenAI Lead for Europe at Infosys) joins us to chat about all things generative AI, and his new book, "Generative AI: Navigating the Course to the Artificial General Intelligence Future."

title: Tony Baer - The Outlook for Generative AI in 2024 (and Beyond)
description:
Veteran data industry analyst Tony Baer joins us to chat about his outlook for generative AI in 2024 and beyond. 

Tony goes way deeper than most people in his analysis, and if you're interested where things are going with generative AI, you better tune into this.

title: Ethan Aaron - Is Data a Job or a Skill?
description: Ethan Aaron (CEO of Portable) joins us to chat about whether data is a job or a skill, what's stopping companies from running their analytics out of a Google Sheet, and much more.

title: Jean-Georges Perrin - Data Mesh, Data Contracts, Modern Data Engineering Standards, Bitol, and More
description: Jean-Georges Perrin joins the show to chat about data mesh, data contracts, modern data engineering standards, Bitol (is open standard project with the Linux Foundation), data architecture, and much more. This is a wide-reaching discussion. Enjoy!

title: Joe and Matt - The Demise of the Modern Data Stack & Listener Q&A
description: Joe Reis and Matt Housley are back for another listener Q&A. They chat about the demise of the Modern Data Stack, architecture, data modeling, AI, and much more.

title: Deadly Beauty: Why Everyone Feels Ugly Now
description:
If youâ€™re struggling, consider therapy with BetterHelp #ad. Click  https://betterhelp.com/elizabethfilips for a 10% discount on your first month of therapy with acredentialed professional specific to your needs ğŸ’š

Itâ€™s hard to be beautiful today, but the sad truth is: it never was much easier. Iâ€™ve been always obsessed with what determines beauty, and have always been interested in the interpretations (and misinterpretations) of evolutionary psychology, modern psychology, anthropology and medicine. I never knew however, just how much economics and politics had to do with it, how much health and disease, money and the church affected what we now consider beautiful or ugly. And even more so, just how much our perceived looks can affect our life. I spent months and months researching and reading about this, satisfying all the curiosities Iâ€™ve had since being a little girl and confusions I still had on just how and why we treat each other and ourselves the way we do. I really hope this gives some information and help to any younger version of Elizabeth out there. 

The second half of the video (timestamped below) is focused mainly on obesity: something Iâ€™m also very passionate about as a soon to be (in a few weeks eeeeek) doctor. I think thereâ€™s so much gaslighting in modern body positivity and so much that remains unsaid but definitely felt and experienced by people everywhere. It might be a bit of a stronger take - but I hope it makes sense! 

I ended up having 135 citations for this video. I worked on it all myself, and this video kind of got out of control from the amount of things I ended up reading and referencing - so reflecting my chaotic mind, I tried my best to keep the citations as clean as possible, but I do apologise if thereâ€™s any repetitions or messy links. The full list was too long for the description, so Iâ€™ve linked a page below with all the books/links/studies referenced. The easiest thing to do is to look at the number of the citation on the video (the rest of the text might be too small in the end for a phone screen) and refer to the page for an easy copy paste if you want to check them out! 

A lot of the historical information was new to me, and I tried my best to find accurate resources and to double and triple check them and go as far back as I could to the original sources - but where thereâ€™s mistakes in what I say in the video, I do apologise and welcome the corrections! 

For a full list of the citations shown (it might be easier to look at the citation number in the video and reference it here): https://www.elizabethfilips.com/post/citations-why-you-will-never-be-beautiful

title: The Complex Psychology of Why Everyone Quits the Gym
description:
Check my Copilot link to get 14 days free with your own personal trainer! https://go.mycopilot.com/elizabeth-filips 
To get a free summary of the book I mentioned, Algorithms to live by - Brian Christian, you can use my link here: http://shortform.com/elizabeth
As a recently-reformed, professional gym-quitter, Iâ€™ve tried everything under the sun for 10 years to try and get myself motivated to work out. And always failed. 10 months into my newfound gym consistency and exercise enjoyment, I re-approached the psychological theories of behavioural change and execise enoyment with a fresh eye (and patience), and summarised the main learning points here. I hope they help explain why quitting the gym is so easy (beyond the usual suspects of laziness and self-hatred) and why quitting, in the case of exercise, might be more of a rational choice than we think. Hope anything here helps for any sort of new habit or behaviour you want to create!

Iâ€™ve spent more time than Iâ€™d like to admit both trying to change my behaviour, and trying to learn how to do it (and why I canâ€™t). Although I do admit doing things comes down to, (shocker) just getting up and doing them, thereâ€™s a lot than can be helped and changed my adjusting my mindset, approach and throughts around behaviour. While I always thought that it was negative emotions, procrastination and vague anxiety holding me back from doing what I wanted, it turns out, it wasnâ€™t that at all. In this video I try to explain (as best I can) what psychologists think is true friction in the way of behavioural change, and how you can understand and apply the same changes to your own life. title: How to Learn Anything Fast: Teach Your Brain to Focus
description:
ğŸ©µ To download a free copy of 80,000 hours to help make the big life decisions, you can follow my link here: https://80000hours.org/filips 
For a free written summary and resources of this video: https://go.elizabethfilips.com/focus

As part of my lifelong battle with focus, I spend a bit too much time trying to find lesser-known or spoken about ways to increase my ability to be able to do what I want to. I particularly love finding out that Iâ€™m already doing something unconsciously to help myself focus, and realising how and why it helps, so I can then do it more intentionally and better - these are the life changes I adore making. Here are my top recent tips on how to focus better, learn better (and faster) and ultimately enjoy life and studying more. Comments and suggestions always welcome! Hope it helps xx 

To make your life easier: 
0:00 Intro
1:00 The neuroscience (& solution) to boredom
3:40 Machine Learning, predictions & surprise
7:59 A new type of attention

title: Why am I lonely around people? The Disturbing Psychology of Friendships
description:
â˜ If you'd like to try out my favourite sleep story for free, the top 500 people to use this link will also get 25% off the yearly subscription for Aura! https://www.aurahealth.io/elizabethfilips

People always say being alone is lonely, but I honestly don't think it even compares to how lonely I feel when I'm around people I love that don't care for me. With friendships either being the happiest and best or the absolute worst thing in my life, here are 5 frameworks for understanding and breaking down why your friendships might not feel as close, loving or caring as we want them to. I've also given journalling prompts for each to break them down! Please please let me know if they're helpful!

To make your life easier:
0:00 Intro
4:34 The Trelawney Principle: sinister "good" friendships
10:58 Why you like bad boys
16:23 Destructive Entitlement: how we are the problem
20:47 How friendships change our brain
24:13 When and how to deal with an ended friendship 
28:07 Catching up on sleep and us

title: Why You Always Quit the Gym: the Science of Enjoying Exercise
description:
Click my CoPilot link https://go.mycopilot.com/ElizabethFilips to get a FREE TRIAL with your own expert fitness and health coach ğŸ’ª
If you need a summary of how un-fit and how much I've always hated exercise: I can't even ride a bike. I always HATED having to move one more step than I strictly need to, I never saw the point or pleasure in voluntarily running on the spot when I could much rather spend that time reading, watching or painting something. And so, it's no surprise that the accumulated uselessness and hatred for working out lead to years of trying to be healthier but always just quitting the gym. For the first time in my life, I've managed to be consistent and actually enjoy exercise with the help and guidance of my personal trainer, so whether or not you can get one too, here's everything mine taught me and all the ways she changed my attitude and behaviours towards exercise. 

0:00 Intro, how Elizabeth can't ride a bike 
4:53 Part 1: what is a good reason to exercise and why it even matters
8:42 Part 2: how to set inspiring exercise and fitness goals
10:22 Part 3: the key ingredients for an enjoyable exercise session 
16:30 Part 4: how to be consistent without being bored and falling off
19:40 Part 5: gym advice for anxious introverts

The study on personalised health risks: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9803971/

title: we're no different.
description:
a story about two generations, transcending through time. 



Meet Shaun Evaristo, a living legend in the dance world whose steps have echoed through time, shaping the rhythm and soul of the entertainment industry. With a career spanning decades, Shaun has not only danced alongside the greats but has himself become a cornerstone for aspiring dancers. His influence is a tapestry woven into the fabric of dance history.

As the spotlight shifts with the arrival of newer generations, Shaun faces the inevitable challenge of time. The industry that once felt like home now whispers of change, and the voice of a younger generation grows louder. It's a crossroads that tests the essence of his passion, pushing him to confront the reality that perhaps his moment in the limelight has dimmed.

Enter Sean Lew, a force from a younger generation. Amidst his ambition, Sean carries a profound respect for the path paved by legends like Shaun. In Sean's eyes, Shaun's legacy is not a relic of the past but a beacon guiding the future of dance. 
But as Sean navigates his own journey towards greatness, his relentless pursuit of perfection begins to cast a shadow over his joy. Caught in the whirlwind of ambition, he loses sight of the essence that first drew him to dance.

It's within this shared space of dreams and doubts that Shaun and Sean forge an unlikely bond. Shaun, with the wisdom of experience, becomes a mentor and a friend to Sean, reminding him that the art of dance is as much about the soul as it is about the steps. Together, they embark on a journey that transcends generations, reminding each other and the world that while the dance may change, the passion that fuels it remains eternal.



directed by: Sean Lew
creative directed: Zev York 
choreography by: Shaun Evaristo & Sean Lew 
edited by: Zev York 
filmed by: Vibrvncy, Gerald Nononato, Jon Shih, Kai Goh, John Kim
performed by: Shaun Evaristo & Sean Lew
stage: Good Times by The Company

title: ARTIST RANGE: The First Document l Short Film by Sean Lew & Karl Flores
description:
Artist Range
Theme No. 1: Krump  
A program created by artist athletes, made for artist athletes.



A special shoutout to EVERY single person who showed up to our very first Artist Range. The growth that everybody has shown through these few weeks, have been insane. LIKE INSANE. we are so so proud and honored to be a part of your journey and hopefully will see you guys in the next. 
until then...... 



Mentors: Karl Flores, Sherwin Solanga, Sean Lew

title: Dial Drunk - Noah Kakan l Sean Lew Choreography l Fairplay Dance Camp 2023
description:
the intention of this piece is about taking that drunk feeling, where things donâ€™t matter as much and just embracing that moment for a second. being the extreme over thinker that i am, this piece was really important for me to teach because i know how pressuring classes can be sometimes. 
so to see the amount of SMILES, TEARS, LAUGHS, HUGS, throughout this classâ€¦. thank you guys for getting â€˜drunkâ€™ with me:) 

god is truly so incredible. i am so lucky and blessed to have moments like these with such beautiful human beings. 


choreography: sean lew 
dancers: kaycee, hannah, sophie 
dial drunk by noah kahan
event: FairPlay Dance Camp

title: 100 Bad Days - AJR | Sean Lew Choreography | Flip The Switch 2023
description:
i didn't know if i was going to actually teach this or not... 

four days before this event, i was in Poland, sitting in the lobby across from Kaycee, deciding what i was going to teach. and with everything going on, I didn't have any time to really prepare a piece, so i thought i would just choose one of my older pieces. But teaching for me, is a very sacred experience for me, especially in LA. 

So i looked at Kaycee and just said 'F**K IT. we are in such a moment of our lives, where we are working so hard and have so much going on, and i'm sure so many other people feel the same. i just want people to understand that being the best at anything is NOT the most important thing. finding the joy and happiness throughout the process is what's important.' 

i will FOREVER cherish classes like these because i get to watch so many dancers smile with each other, mess up with each other, laugh with each other, cheer each other on. THAT is dance. THAT is community. THAT is life. 

so this piece is reminder for people like us who work so hard, that we forget to play hard too... 


Thank you Alex and Jasmine for the incredible event and for having me. 
Thank you Vibrvncy for the impeccable captures. 
Thank you Kaycee for the forever golden moments that I always cherish. 



Danced by: Kaycee Rice & Sean Lew 
Choreography: Sean Lew
Filmed by: Gerald Nonato, Kai Goh
Event: Flip The Switch (Los Angeles)

  plot_layout(widths=c(2, 1))

  plot_layout(widths=c(2, 1), heights=c(5, 1))

  plot_annotation(tag_levels="I")
(p1 + p2) / p3 + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels="A")

library(grid)
p1 + textGrob("Negative Relationship!!!")

library(gridExtra)
p1 + gtableGrob(mtcars[1:10, c("mpg", "wt")])
